## PHQ-9 vs SCARED

Comparing questionnaires in psychological research such as the PHQ-9 vs SCARED questionnaires can be time-consuming and subjective. Psychologists and social scientists often end up spending more time on this process, known as harmonisation, rather than focusing on their core research. A solution to this problem is a software called Harmony. Harmony uses natural language processing and AI technology to compare psychological questionnaires in order to aid researchers in their harmonisation process.

## Compare the items in PHQ-9 and SCARED English (adult)

* <a href="https://harmonydata.ac.uk/app/#" target="harmonyapp">Import PHQ-9 and SCARED (adult) into Harmony and harmonise them</a> - find similarities between the two instruments using our AI platform
* <a href="https://harmonydata.ac.uk/app/#" target="harmonyapp">Import just PHQ-9 into Harmony</a> - compare PHQ-9 with other instruments
* <a href="https://harmonydata.ac.uk/app/#" target="harmonyapp">Import just SCARED (adult) into Harmony</a> - compare SCARED English (adult) with other instruments


Harmony has the ability not only to compare standardised questionnaires like the PHQ-9 vs SCARED (adult), but also user-submitted questionnaire data in a variety of languages. This immensely simplifies multi-lingual and cross-study comparison. Its well-developed database and web interface allows for easy drag-and-drop uploading or selection of questionnaires. For example, the comparison of PHQ-9 vs SCARED (adult) can be done in a matter of clicks, saving researchers valuable time. In today’s world of data-driven research, making full use of the cohort and longitudinal studies requires accurate and efficient harmonisation. Harmony’s ability to provide a percentage match between each item of the two instruments, like PHQ-9 vs SCARED (adult), makes it an invaluable tool for any researchers wanting to compare exercise across various studies, verify consistent findings, or explore the impact of changing social conditions on results. Harmony is truly a game-changer in psychological research harmonisation.
